text.p: LME aluminium kept up its relentless rise on Monday afternoon, ratcheting up to a 22-month high, but some of the other metals eased on profit-taking and trade selling.
In Chicago, the Commodities Research Bureau index gained 1.90 points to 245.26.
On the LME, three months aluminium touched $1,747 per tonne, the highest since early October 1995, as tightness bubbled under the market. It ended the afternoon kerb $5 firmer at $1,744.
Zinc also finished the day stronger, adding $31 to $1,494 as borrowing interest in spreads underpinned prices.
Copper continued its short-term downtrend, losing grip of the $2,300 mark as stocks kept rising. Prices shed $27.50 to $2,282, with support pegged at $2,270 and $2,250.
Nickel fell back under profit-taking after a strike at Canada's Falconbridge failed to spark interest. Only an extended strike would impact on the fundamentals, analysts said.
Trade selling hit tin, which lost $55 to $5,585 after several days of speculative gains.
Lead moved sideways again in a narrow range, ending $2 easier at $637.
Alloy closed slightly weaker at $1,530/35, down from $1,540.

COMEX and NYMEX precious metals futures ended higher, with the exception of gold, as platinum futures climbed to fresh contract highs, and palladium futures ended locked limit up for the second day in row. In the bullion market, spot gold ended quoted $323.65/15, compared with the London Monday afternoon fix at $323.55 and the New York close Friday at $324.40/90.

IPE September Brent crude oil ended Monday some 50 cents higher on a combination of bullish factors, brokers said. The contract closed up a half a dollar at $19.45 a barrel, off the late intraday high of $19.64. News that Occidental Petroleum had shut in production and declared force majeure in the Colombian Cano Limon crude field for the second time in three weeks saw prices soar.

CBOT soft red winter wheat futures closed lower, pulled down by a drop in corn and soybean futures, traders said. Forecasts for rain later in the week in the U.S. Midwest knocked CBOT corn and soybeans lower after a higher opening, they said. CBOT soft red winter wheat futures closed 4-1/2 to 7-1/2 cents per bushel lower, with September down 6-3/4 at $3.54-3/4 per bushel. December closed seven cents lower at $3.69-1/2.
Last trades or bids for key Australian-interest commodities.
Copper Grade A (LME cash official US$/tonne) 2314 ( 2338)
Zinc High Grade (LME cash official US$/tonne) 1570 ( 1558)
